ğŸ“– Vol 1: Arrangement of Litanies
And if one recites the ten seven-times-repeated [verses] that Al-Khidr (peace be upon him) gifted to Ibrahim Al-Taymi (may Allah have mercy on him) and advised him to say them morning and evening, then he has attained complete virtue and gathered for himself the excellence of all the mentioned supplications. It has been narrated from Kurz ibn Wabrah (may Allah have mercy on him), who was among the Substitutes (Al-Abdal), that he said: A brother of mine from the people of Ash-Sham came to me and gifted me a gift and said: O Kurz, accept from me this gift, for it is an excellent gift. I said: O my brother, and who gifted you this gift? He said: Ibrahim Al-Taymi gave it to me. I said: Did you not ask Ibrahim who gave it to him? He said: I was sitting in the courtyard of the Kaaba while I was engaged in declaring the Oneness (At-Tahlil), glorification (At-Tasbih), praise (At-Tahmid), and magnification (At-Tamjid) of Allah. A man came to me, greeted me with peace, and sat to my right. I have never seen in my time anyone with a more beautiful face, nor more beautiful clothes, nor more intense whiteness, nor more pleasant fragrance than him. I said: O servant of Allah, who are you and from where have you come? He said: I am Al-Khidr. I said: For what have you come to me? He said: I have come to you to greet you with peace and out of love for you for the sake of Allah, and I have a gift I wish to present to you. I said: What is it? He said: That you say before the rising of the sun, before its spreading over the earth, and before sunset: Surah Al-Hamd (Al-Fatihah), and 'Say: I seek refuge with the Lord of mankind (Qul A'udhu bi-Rabbi an-Nas)', and 'Say: I seek refuge with the Lord of the daybreak (Qul A'udhu bi-Rabbi al-Falaq)', and 'Say: He is Allah, the One (Qul Huwa Allahu Ahad)', and 'Say: O you who disbelieve (Qul Ya Ayyuha al-Kafirun)', and the Verse of the Throne (Ayat al-Kursi), each one seven times. And you say: Glory be to Allah (Subhan Allah), and praise be to Allah (Al-Hamdu Lillah), and there is no god but Allah (La Ilaha Illa Allah), and Allah is the Greatest (Allahu Akbar) seven times. And you send prayers upon the Prophet (peace be upon him) seven times. And you seek forgiveness for yourself, your parents, the believing men, and the believing women seven times. And you say: O Allah, do with me and with them, immediately and later, in religion, this world, and the Hereafter, what You are worthy of, and do not do with us, O our Master, what we are worthy of, for You are Forgiving, Forbearing, Generous, Noble, Compassionate, Merciful seven times. And see that you do not abandon that morning and evening.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Prayer
If his standing, facing (the Qibla), and bowing his head have become balanced in this manner, then let him recite 'Say: I seek refuge with the Lord of mankind (Qul a'udhu bi-rabbi al-nas)' as a fortification with it from Satan. Then let him come with the Iqamah (call to commence prayer), and if he hopes for the presence of someone who will follow him, let him give the Adhan (call to prayer) first. Then let him bring forth the intention (Niyyah), which is that he intends for the Dhuhr (noon prayer), for example, and says in his heart (Qalb): 'I perform the obligatory (Fard) prayer of Dhuhr for Allah,' to distinguish it by his saying 'I perform' from making up a missed prayer (Qada'), and by 'obligatory' from voluntary (Nafl), and by 'Dhuhr' from 'Asr (afternoon prayer) and others. And let the meanings of these words be present in his heart (Qalb), for that is the intention (Niyyah), and the words are reminders (Mudhakkirat) and causes for their presence.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Etiquette of Quran Recitation
The eighth [practice] is that he should say at the beginning of his recitation: 'I seek refuge with Allah, the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing, from the accursed Satan (Shaytan).' 'My Lord (Rabb), I seek refuge with You from the whisperings of the devils (Shayateen), and I seek refuge with You, my Lord (Rabb), lest they be present with me.' And let him recite 'Say: I seek refuge with the Lord (Rabb) of mankind' and the Chapter of Praise (Surah Al-Fatihah) for Allah. And let him say upon completing his recitation: 'Allah the Exalted has spoken the truth, and His Messenger has conveyed it. O Allah, benefit us by it and bless us in it. All praise is due to Allah, the Lord (Rabb) of the worlds, and I seek forgiveness from Allah, the Ever-Living, the Self-Sustaining.'

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
And the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah is what secures its side and one knows that there is no opportunity for the Devil (Shaytan) in it, and a thing is not treated except by its opposite, and the opposite of all the whisperings (Waswas) of the Devil (Shaytan) is the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah through seeking refuge (Isti'adha) and disavowing power and strength, and that is the meaning of your saying: 'I seek refuge in Allah from the accursed Devil (Shaytan)' and 'There is no power nor strength except with Allah, the Most High, the Most Great.' And that is not capable of it except the God-fearing (Muttaqun) upon whom the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah predominates. Indeed, the Devil (Shaytan) only circles around them in times of lapses (Falatat) by way of stealth. Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, those who fear Allah, when an impulse from the Devil (Shaytan) touches them, they remember, and at once they have insight.' And Mujahid said regarding the meaning of the saying of Allah the Exalted: 'From the evil of the whisperer (Waswas) who withdraws (Khannas),' he said: 'He is spread out upon the Heart (Qalb), so when Allah is remembered, he withdraws (Khannasa) and contracts, and when one is heedless, he spreads out upon his Heart (Qalb).' So the chasing away between the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah and the whispering (Waswas) of the Devil (Shaytan) is like the chasing away between light and darkness and between night and day. And due to their opposition, Allah the Exalted said: 'The Devil (Shaytan) has gained mastery over them and made them forget the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah.'
